title: Spurned man demands £42.50 from woman he met on Plenty of Fish after she turns down second date - Mirror Online
text:

A woman was left stunned after a man she ditched after just one date sent his bank details and demanded that she refund him the cash he spent on drinks. 
Even though the date went well and Lucy Brown, 38, thought the man was "normal and sweet", she texted him to let him know she wasn't interested in a second date. 
The Londoner couldn't believe it when he replied to tell her he was "devastated" and he wanted a "contribution" for the drinks he bought her. 
The man she met on Plenty of Fish told her to pay "her share" - £42.50 - and gave his bank account number and sort code at the bottom of the WhatsApp message. The man told Lucy he had spent around £85 on their date (Photo: Mercury Press) 
Lucy was only on her second date after joining the dating apps Plenty of Fish and Tinder after her three-year long relationship ended just before Christmas last year. Read More Daters with learning disabilities slam OkCupid for refusing to scrap question asking 'should people with low IQ be stopped from having kids' 
The pair met at a pub in Clapham, south London, on February 4. 
After she had ended up taking his watch home by mistake, he even informed her it was worth £20 but told he not to post it back because "it'd be too painful to receive the watch in the post and remind me of you". 
Lucy's hilarious reply informed the man that she had paid him his £42.50 back and donated the same amount again to a donkey sanctuary, claiming she had never laughed so hard. 
Lucy, a clothes designer, said: "I thought he seemed really nice and normal, with a good profession as I'm a career girl and he seemed quite sensible. 
"I have been a bit of a date monster [before my last relationship], but I'd only been on one other date with someone else before I met him. 
"When I got the text, I was crying with laughter - I honestly thought he was joking. But then I realised he was serious. Lucy says she thought the man's message was a joke (Photo: Mercury Press) 
"Everyone in my office has been snorting and crying with laughter at the text too. Read More 'Professional dater' makes more than £12,000 in a year from lonely men through 'sugar daddy' website 
"People have just been like 'oh my god, is he joking' after seeing the message." 
In the text, the man expresses his adoration and disappointment at being jilted and says he had saved up to take her on a nice date. 
The text reads: "As it didn't work out I'd be grateful if you could send along something to contribute for the drinks I spent on you thinking I'd at least get to see you again. 
"The total cost of the night was c.£85, and as it'd be too painful to receive the watch in the post and remind me of you I thought that you might be interested to know the cost of that was 20. Happy for you to do what you feel is right, especially considering my badly damaged feelings atm." 
Lucy said: "I am a bit surprised - how can he be so devastated about just one date? 
"I only ended up with his watch because we were both messing around and he was wearing my hat, so in return he gave me it to wear. Read More How you can survive Valentine's Day if you're broken-hearted 
"When we both went to say goodbye we both forgot I still had his watch on." 
She added: "He has since messaged back and he put 'I feel like the donkey sanctuary has come out better from this situation'. I just text him back saying 'eeyore'." 
Lucy's dating life has become such a topic of ridicule in her office that her colleagues even suggested she write a book about her misfortune and include dating disasters from both her and her friend's experiences on Tinder and other dating apps. 
She added: "I'd say this guy who asked for his money back was definitely the weirdest date I'd ever had." Like us on Facebook
